overall_summary: The reasoning demonstrates a practical approach to forecasting short time-series data with clear daily seasonality. Given the limited historical data (only 4 days) and a long forecast horizon (96 steps), the analyst prioritizes simplicity and interpretability over complex models. The solution focuses on identifying patterns, handling data constraints, and implementing a heuristic method that captures daily cycles while acknowledging data limitations.
common_data_patterns: Complete historical data (no missing values in provided window)
key_insights: Limited data (4 days) necessitates simple methods over complex models like SARIMA/ETS
Hourly averaging effectively captures daily seasonality when trends are absent
Rounding forecasts to match original data precision (3 decimal places)
Timestamp generation for multi-day forecasts requires calendar awareness (e.g., non-leap year)
Explicit handling of the forecast horizon (96 steps) through pattern repetition
complexity_analysis: Moderately complex with strong emphasis on data pattern analysis and practical constraints. Balances statistical considerations (seasonality detection, averaging) with heuristic implementation, avoiding computationally intensive models due to data limitations.
